millsfield:images_texts:
The Chef
the
"Day
FIRST CLASS
SABENA
BELGIAN WORLD AIRLINES

Pens Hoffyn
A kint of autumn in the air
Seasonal treats in store for top-class tastebuds
Cooking is in René Stoffyn's blood. The Belgian
master-chef is the fifth checking generation of his family
to satisfy the palates of customers at their restaurant Le
Centenaire, just down the road from the celebrated
Brussels landmark the Atomium. This month, Stoffyn
takes over a three-month stint supervising meals served
to First and Business Class passengers on outbound
Sabena flights to Tokyo and Johannesburg, and return
journeys from New York.
Stoffyn is accustomed to catering for people at the
top. Over the years, Le Centenaire has been patronised
by many celebrities, among them Jane Birkin, Charles
Aznavour, Coluche, Billy Ocean, and Gérard Depardieu.
For his spell as Sabena's guest Maître Cuisinier,
Stoffyn has devised a series of unique autumn menus for
the three long-haul routes, ranging from between-meal
snacks to gourmet dinners, served inflight on porcelain
plates with white table linen. Among the mouthwatering
dishes Stoffyn has dreamed up, to make each journey
a memorable experience, are duck wings cooked in Kriek
beer with black cherry sauce, and
venison cutlets
flavoured with autumn herbs, all to be accompanied by
a carefully-chosen selection of fine vintage wines.
These special menus have been many months in the
planning. "Haute cuisine is a bit like haute couture,"
says Stoffyn with a smile. "You have to work a season
in advance." The Belgian chef even flew across the
Atlantic, to advise catering staff who prepare Sabena's
meals on the New York-Brussels route. The cuisine, he
explains, is "two thirds traditional French, one third
modern and innovative."
Stoffyn says he has enjoyed the challenge of planning
meals for Sabena passengers. "It is completely different
from ordinary catering. You have to formulate a menu
according to what is possible on board. For example, a
sauce Bearnaise is out because it has to be prepared just
before serving, otherwise it goes sour."
And he adds that inflight diners can be even more
demanding than those down on the ground. "People pay
more attention to what they eat when they are aboard
a plane, because they have nothing else to do."
